Talend ESB Getting Started Guide 10 March 2011
Talend ESB Runtime Team
2011 Talend Corporation
Overview
The Enterprise Service Bus (ESB) has always been the cornerstone of every vendor's Service Oriented Architecture (SOA) strategy. In the past, however, ESBs have often failed to help leverage the full value of SOA. This was due to their large footprint, centralized architecture, and considerable effort required to properly integrate them into an existing application landscape. Unlike these ESB solutions Talend ESB has relatevely small size, using of proven open source technologies allows to create and coordinate work of distributed, highly reliable business applications without much effort.
In this Getting Started Guide you will learn about Talend ESB/CXF. This guide contains a simplified real-world example, using the domain of car rental companies to demonstrate the use of Talend ESB for developing and deploying services.
You will first learn the design of the Rent a Car Demo. Then we will show how to compile the demo, deploy it into the Talend ESB Runtime OSGi container and then activate it. You will also learn how to enable the Service Locator Component for the Rent a Car demo, and how Service Activity Monitoring can be enabled.
Rent a Car Demo Example
For this demo example we have chosen a common business use case scenario: a simplified real-world example from the domain of car rental companies.
In the course of working through this example you will learn how to:
compile and build Apache CXF services, deploy services using the Karaf OSGi console, use OSGi commands
In this scenario, there are two main services that will be demonstrated, CRMService and ReservationService. You will create and orchestrate these services with the help of a simple graphical front-end application.
Rental Client provides the basic functionality to search for the available cars within a given time period. The search takes into account the status (silver, gold, platinum) of the given user. This criteria will then determine the outcome of the search. From the list of results you can select the car that best fulfills your requirements and then make your reservation simply by clicking on the "Book" button. At the end of the submission process, the system will show you a confirmation page with your Reservation ID. To implement its business logic the client calls operations of both the CRM Service and the Reservation Service.
How to build the Demo
System Requirements
The Talend ESB and examples can be installed, built, and run on Windows or UNIX-style operating systems for which Java 6 is available. The following software is required for installing, building, and running the samples:
JDK 1.6.0 from Oracle should be installed, and the environment variable JAVA_HOME should be set to the JDK installation directory. Later JDKs from Oracle or JDKs from other providers may work but have not been tested.
Maven 3.0.3 or better from Apache should be installed, and the mvn executable should be in your PATH. When running mvn, HTTP access to the internet is required.
Installation of the Talend ESB
The Talend ESB is provided as two archives. For Windows, these are talend-esb-<version>.zip and talend-esb-<version>-doc.zip, for UNIX/Linux talend-esb-<version>.tar.gz and talend-esb-<version>-doc.tar.gz (<version> is replaced by the ESB version, e.g. "4.0"). Both archives should be unpacked to a directory of your choice. There, a directory talend-esb-<version> is created which contains ESB and examples. Directory paths mentioned in the following chapters will by default be relative to this directory.
Rent a Car Demo structure
CRMService sample
This sample is found in directory talend-esb-<version>/examples/tesb/crmservice/. It consists of three parts:
Sample part
Description
common/ This directory contains the CRMService.wsdl which is used to generate the initial code.
service/ This is where the CRMService service implementation shared by JAX-WS endpoints is located
client/ This is a sample client application that shows how CXF JAX-WS proxies invoke remote JAX-WS endpoints hosting the CRMService interface
ReservationService sample
This sample is found in directory talend-esb-<version>/examples/tesb/reservationservice/. It consists of 3 parts:
Sample part
Description
common/ This directory contains the ReservationService.wsdl which is used to generate the initial code.
service/ This is where the ReservationService implementation shared by JAX-WS endpoints is located.
client/ This is a sample client application that shows how CXF JAX-WS proxies invoke remote JAX-WS endpoints represented by the ReservationService interface.
"app-reservation" project bundle
Directory talend-esb-<version>/examples/tesb/app-reservation/ contains the Maven project for creating the car reservation sample application OSGi bundle.
Building the "Rent a Car" Demo sample
From the base directory of the ESB sample, i.e. talend-esb-<version>/examples/tesb/, the Maven project file pom.xml can be used to build the demo. After changing to this directory, Maven is invoked equally from a UNIX/Linux terminal or the Windows command line:
mvn clean install
Running this command, the demo is built, and OSGi bundles are created for deployment into an OSGi container.
Deploying the "Rent a Car" demo in the Talend ESB Runtime OSGi container
Create a secondary OSGi container
One OSGi container is included in the installation in sub-directory container. However, for trying out all aspects of the examples it is recommended to have two OSGI containers. This can be achieved by the following procedure:
Create a copy of directory container with all its content. In a UNIX/Linux terminal resp. on the Windows command line, change the current directory to talend-esb-<version>. From there, under UNIX/Linux execute the following command:
cp -r container alternate-container
Under Windows, execute the following command instead:
robocopy /e container alternate-container
Now, you have a second OSGi container in directory alternate-container.
In order to avoid conflicts between the two container instances, the configuration of the alternate-container needs to be adapted. For this purpose open the configuration file alternate-container/etc/org.apache.karaf.management.cfg in your favourite text editor. Search line
rmiRegistryPort = 1099
and replace it with
rmiRegistryPort = 1199
or another unused port.
Now, two OSGi containers are available for running the examples.
Start the OSGi console
Start the OSGi container running program talend-esb-<version>/container/bin/tesb (UNIX/Linux) resp. talend-esb-<version>\container\bin\tesb.bat (Windows).
Under UNIX/Linux, go to directory talend-esb-<version> and execute the following command:
./container/bin/tesb
Under Windows, go to directory talend-esb-<version> and execute the following command:
.\container\bin\tesb.bat
The second container is started up the same way. Just replace ./container/... by ./alternate-container/....
When the container starts up, you will see a short introduction followed by the OSGi console command prompt:
karaf@tesb>
The OSGi commands explained in the following sections will be entered here.
You can find further information about the OSGi container used by the TESB and how to get started it at the "Karaf" site http://karaf.apache.org/.
Deploy the demo services
Add the "Rent A Car" feature location into the OSGi container.
At the OSGi console prompt, type the following command:
features:addurl mvn:org.talend.esb.examples/features/4.0/xml
Remark: This command refers to version "4.0" of the Talend ESB. If you are using another version, replace the version sub-string .../4.0/... by the number of your version.
Install the "Rent A Car" services feature into the OSGi container.
Type the followin console command:
features:install tesb-rac-services
Check feature installation success.
Type the following console command:
list
You will see the demo bundles in the list of installed bundles:
[ 137] [Active ] [ ] [ ] [ 60] CRMService Common (4.0.0) [ 138] [Active ] [ ] [ ] [ 60] ReservationService Common (4.0.0) [ 139] [Active ] [ ] [ ] [ 60] CRMService Service (4.0.0) [ 140] [Active ] [ ] [Started] [ 60] CRMService Service Endpoint (4.0.0) [ 141] [Active ] [ ] [ ] [ 60] ReservationService Service (4.0.0) [ 142] [Active ] [ ] [Started] [ 60] ReservationService Service Endpoint (4.0.0)
If you later want to uninstall the demo services, e.g. because you want to move them to the other container or try another scenario, execute this command at the OSGi console:
features:uninstall tesb-rac-services
Then, you can install them again as described above.
Deploy the demo application
The demo application can be deployed in the same OSGi container as the service or in the second container.
If the second container is used for deployment of the demo application, add the "Rent A Car" feature location into this OSGi container. The feature location needs to be added only once in each container, even if the container is shut down afterwards and re-started. However, if unsure, you may add the feature location again at any time.
At the OSGi console prompt, type the following command:
features:addurl mvn:org.talend.esb.examples/features/4.0/xml
Remark: This command refers to version "4.0" of the Talend ESB. If you are using another version, replace the version sub-string .../4.0/... by the number of your version.
Install the "Rent A Car" application feature into the OSGi container.
Type the following console command:
features:install tesb-rac-app
Check feature installation success.
Type the following console command:
list
You will see the demo bundles in the list of installed bundles:
[ 137] [Active ] [ ] [ ] [ 60] CRMService Common (4.0.0) [ 138] [Active ] [ ] [ ] [ 60] ReservationService Common (4.0.0) [ 139] [Active ] [ ] [Started] [ 60] CRMService Client (4.0.0) [ 140] [Active ] [ ] [Started] [ 60] ReservationService Client (4.0.0) [ 141] [Active ] [Created ] [Started] [ 60] App Reservation (4.0.0)
If you later want to uninstall the demo application, e.g. because you want to move it to the other container, execute this command at the OSGi console:
features:uninstall tesb-rac-app
Then, you can install it again as described above.
How to run the "Rent a Car" demo
Use Case Scenario for "Rent a Car"
A customer enters prerequisite data into a form such as her name, the pick-up and return dates, the preferred range of rental rates, and submits her query.
Next, the application calls the CRMService to retrieve the customer data and customer status information.
The customer is presented a list of available cars and selects one car from the list.
Finally, the application calls the ReservationService to submit the reservation request and then displays a reservation confirmation notice to the customer.
Starting the application
ReservationService, CRMService, and App-reservation are already deployed in Talend ESB Runtime. Start the OSGi console as described previously. If demo services and demo application are deployed in two different containers, both must be started.
On the console of the container with the demo application you will see:
---TALEND ESB: Rent a Car (OSGi) Commands--- car:GUI (Show GUI) car:search <user> <pickupDate> <returnDate> (Search for cars to rent, date format yyyy/mm/dd) car:rent <pos> (Rent a car listed in search result of carSearch)
Using the TALEND ESB "Rental Client GUI"
To start the GUI, type car:GUI in the console window.
Select "aebert" from the drop-down box.
Click Find to see the results. You will see the list of available cars.
Click the highlighted line or select any other option and click "Reserve".
You will now see the confirmation page:
Click Close to stop the application.
Using the "search" command
In the console type:
car:search aebert 2011/01/26 2011/01/26
You will see the list of available cars:
Found 5 cars.
Car details 1 VW Golf Standard 50.00 75.00 40.00 2 BMW 320i Sport 60.00 90.00 45.00 3 Mazda MX5 Sport 65.00 95.00 50.00 4 Lexus LX400 SUV 85.00 120.00 100.00 5 Mercedes E320 Delux 95.00 140.00 100.00
Using the "rent" command
In the console type: car:rent 2
You can now see the confirmation:
Reservation ID SGA-686277
Customer details ---------------- Name: Andrea Ebert eMail: info@sopera.de City: Munich Status: PLATINUM
Car details ----------- Brand: BMW Model: 320i
Reservation details ------------------- Pick up date: 2011/01/26 Return date: 2011/01/26 Daily rate: 60.00 Weekend rate: 90.00 Credits: 210 Thank you for renting a car with Talend ESB :-)
How to enable the sample in Eclipse
For more information about how to use the Maven Eclipse Plugin read http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-eclipse-plugin/
For generating the Eclipse configuration files from the base directory of the ESB sample talend-esb-<version>/examples/tesb run: mvn eclipse:eclipse.
In the Eclipse IDE
From the main menu bar, select "File > Import...". The Import wizard opens.
Select "General > Existing Project into Workspace" and click "Next".
Choose "Select root directory" and click the associated "Browse" to locate the ESB sample directory.
Under "Projects" select the project or projects which you would like to import.
Click "Finish" to start the import.
The TESB sample projects are imported into the workspace and it is possible to see the sources, modify them, and to take advantage of all the eclipse features.
However, the TESB sample projects cannot be run in the Eclipse IDE.
